Honored to host Charlie, a remarkable young man from Michigan's 5th District. Charlie is in D.C. to share his story of fighting a pediatric brain tumor. It was a pleasure to take him on the House floor to meet representatives, including @SpeakerMcCarthy.

Autoworkers remember the Trump administration when we had abundant energy, cheap gas, and low inflation.

The difference is on display this week in Michigan.

Advancing the CARS Act is a big win for consumers, innovation, and America’s auto industry.

Unattainable and unaffordable government mandates should not dictate the future instead of American ingenuity and consumer choice.

Included today is my CARS Act to block the Biden administration from implementing their burdensome EV mandates that limit consumer choice.

Consumers should decide what car they want to drive, and innovation should guide the auto industry's future, not government mandates.

We must ensure that American innovation will continue to lead the world as we look toward the future.

We must also eliminate national security risks that CCP-affiliated companies pose by collecting data on American roadways and people through AV testing.

Pressed Secretary Granholm on the Biden administration’s overbearing auto rules that will limit consumer choice and create uncertainty for our electric grid. The Biden administration must abandon unrealistic regulations and provide real solutions to lower energy costs.

I’ve been to the southern border during both the Trump and Biden eras, and there couldn’t be a starker difference.  

We went from strong border security measures to seeing materials sit unused while agents are overwhelmed. H.R. 2 returns us to policies that keep Americans safe.

Thousands of migrants are expected to pour across the border as @POTUS allows Title 42 to expire today.

With several colleagues on both sides of the aisle, I have introduced the bipartisan Telehealth Benefit Expansion for Workers Act, legislation that would expand access to telehealth services by classifying them as an excepted benefit for employer-sponsored coverage.
While the emergency health declaration dragged out for years, damaging the reputation of public health agencies, the administration did not adequately prepare for the transition to complete normalcy.

One of the silver linings of the pandemic era has been telehealth flexibility which is widely popular and helps better serve rural and underserved communities.

As a stand-alone benefit, telehealth disproportionally helps retail, hospitality, and health care employees.

Today the public health emergency will finally end. Despite @POTUS declaring the pandemic was over more than 6 months ago, the Biden admin has failed to provide solid answers on the future of telehealth as a stand-alone benefit.
